system.description:
The immortal master of Barovus. Four centuries ago, Lord-Governor Strahd von Zarovich was the most decorated Imperial commander in the subsector — a brilliant strategist who conquered this world for the Imperium through sheer tactical genius and ruthless efficiency. When the brother he loved was ordained as a Ministorum priest and wed the woman Strahd coveted, he bargained with a Daemon Prince of Slaanesh for immortality, murdered Sergei on his wedding night, and damned the entire world.

He appears as a tall, gaunt man in archaic officer's regalia — dress uniform of a pattern not worn for four hundred years, immaculately maintained. His features are noble but corpse-pale, cheekbones sharp as blades, eyes burning with cold warp-light that shifts between violet and pale gold. His voice is a deep, cultured baritone. He moves with the fluid precision of a master swordsman and the patience of something that has all the time in the world.

After four centuries, Strahd is profoundly, dangerously BORED. He has read every book, mastered every skill, broken every soul on Barovus. The Acolytes are the first interesting thing to happen in decades. He will toy with them, test them, invite them to dinner, compliment their courage, and ultimately try to destroy everything they care about — not from malice, but because their suffering is the only thing that makes him feel alive.

He loves Tatyana/Ireena with the obsessive, possessive love of a collector for a masterwork. Every generation she reincarnates, and every generation she dies before he can claim her. This is his curse, and he refuses to accept it.

system.description: Strahd's personal weapon. An archaic Imperial power sword of extraordinary craftsmanship, maintained over four centuries.
Integrated into Strahd's augmented form. Short range but devastating.
Archaic carapace armour sustained and reinforced by centuries of warp-infusion. AP 8 all locations.
Master control signet ring for Zarovich Spire. Activates lair actions, commands servitors, seals/opens all doors.
Allows instantaneous relocation to any point within Zarovich Spire. Spire only — does not function outside.

An elderly Ordo Malleus Inquisitor who has been trapped on Barovus for twenty-seven years, surviving through extreme competence, ruthlessness, and a refusal to die. He hides in Fortress Vallak under the identity 'Dr. Richtus,' a travelling physician — a cover that lets him move freely while gathering intelligence on Strahd.

His face is a roadmap of scars. One eye is augmetic, clicking faintly as it refocuses. His hands are steady but liver-spotted, and he moves with the careful economy of a man who knows exactly how much strength he has left. He speaks with quiet authority, each word chosen with the precision of a man who has learned that careless speech kills.

Van Richten arrived on Barovus with a full retinue — acolytes, savants, a combat servitor. All dead within three years. He carries their names like wounds. He talks to them sometimes, in the small hours, when he thinks no one can hear. He trusts no one, least of all himself. Prone to long suspicious silences and sudden agitation.

His core conviction remains unbroken: duty to the Inquisition, duty to the Emperor. He wants to destroy Strahd, redeem his failure, and die with purpose. He will not reveal his true identity unless the Acolytes demonstrate genuine competence and commitment. Once convinced, he becomes an invaluable ally — not as a combatant, but as a strategist and intelligence source.

system.description: Van Richten's sidearm. Loaded with blessed bolt rounds effective against warp-touched entities.
A well-maintained mono-edged sword. Van Richten's backup weapon.
Van Richten's specialized weapon for hunting warp-touched entities. Fires blessed silver-tipped stakes.
Battered carapace armour maintained over 27 years on Barovus. AP 5 body, AP 4 limbs.
Personal hexagrammic wards inscribed on sub-dermal plates. +10 WP vs daemonic psychic powers.
Decades of intelligence on Strahd, warp-thralls, Barovus geography, and the three destruction conditions. Grants +20 to relevant Lore tests when consulted.

The latest reincarnation of Tatyana — the woman Strahd murdered his brother to possess, and who has died in every incarnation before he could claim her. Ireena does not know any of this. She knows only that the Lord-Governor is obsessed with her, that her adopted father died trying to protect her, and that something is awakening inside her mind.

She is a young woman with dark hair and pale, sharp features — striking rather than beautiful, with eyes that seem to look through people rather than at them. She carries an autopistol she barely knows how to use, and wears her father's aquila pendant.

Ireena is brave, intelligent, practical, and deeply compassionate. She is also angry — at Strahd, at her helplessness, at the entire situation. She does not trust easily and she will not be a passive damsel. She will fight, argue, make her own decisions, sometimes to the Acolytes' frustration. She is grieving her father but functional.

She feels a strange, unwanted pull toward Strahd — a residual soul-bond from centuries of reincarnation. She hates this. She loves Ismark deeply and worries about his self-destructive protectiveness.

Her latent psychic abilities are emerging under the stress of the campaign — precognitive flashes, empathic sensitivity, and an involuntary psychic scream when directly threatened. Each use risks psychic phenomena and draws the attention of warp-sensitive entities.

system.description: Ireena barely knows how to use this. She has fired it twice.
Burgomaster Kolyan's aquila pendant. No mechanical effect, but deeply personal. Ireena will not willingly part with it.

Ireena's brother and the son of the late Burgomaster Kolyan of Barovus Village. Ismark served three years in the planetary defence militia — close enough to Imperial Guard training to make him a competent fighter, far enough from real war to leave him unprepared for what Barovus has become.

He is broad-shouldered and solid, with the calloused hands of a man who works the land when he isn't fighting. His face is open and honest — a terrible quality on Barovus. He wears battered flak armour and carries a chainsword he maintains with religious devotion.

Ismark is practical, brave, and deeply protective of Ireena — sometimes to a self-destructive degree. He will fight to the death to protect her without hesitation. He is not reckless, but he is not clever either; he follows orders well and fights steadily, but complex plans confuse him. He is grieving his father and terrified for his sister, though he hides both behind a mask of gruff competence.

He drinks too much Vostra spirit and sleeps too little. He is a good man in a place where goodness is a liability.

system.description: Militia-issue chainsword, lovingly maintained. Ismark's most prized possession after his sister.
Standard sidearm. Two spare clips.
Battered militia-issue flak armour. No helmet.

A Magos-Biologis of the Adeptus Mechanicus who came to Barovus decades ago on a research expedition and never left. The warp rift corroded his logic-engines and his sanity in equal measure. He now operates out of the Krezk Biologis Facility — once a legitimate medicae installation, now a charnel house of unethical experimentation.

Abaron is a grotesque fusion of corroded machinery and pulsing, mutated flesh. His body is largely hidden beneath augmetics, stained robes, and professional apparatus. His face is unnaturally smooth and waxy — he has been practicing flesh-sculpting on himself. His eyes are multi-spectral augmetic lenses that whir and refocus constantly. His hands are the real horror: surgical tools fused directly into his fingers, blades and syringes extending from his knuckles, the boundary between tool and flesh deliberately erased.

He retains the cold logic and obsessive focus of the Mechanicus, but warped into something grotesque. He speaks calmly and precisely about procedures that would make a Chirurgeon vomit. He genuinely believes he is helping. He regards organ harvesting, flesh-sculpting, and constructing abominable servitor-constructs from the villagers of Krezk as necessary steps toward salvation.

His project: building a 'perfect vessel' — a bride for Strahd, constructed from harvested biological components. He believes completing this gift will earn Krezk's freedom. He does not recognize that his plan is morally abhorrent and practically impossible.

He is the only individual on Barovus who can maintain cybernetics — at escalating moral cost (1d5 CP per visit).

system.description: Four prehensile mechadendrites, each tipped with surgical tools and grasping claws.
qualities: May attack with up to 4 per round as Full Action

system.description: Built into Abaron's augmented frame.
A syringe-tipped claw that injects paralytic compounds.
qualities: Toxic — target must pass Toughness test or –20 all tests for 1d10 rounds

system.description:
The ancient matriarch of the Vostra — a clan of warp-touched Rogue Traders who navigate the mists of Barovus where others go mad. She is impossibly old. No one knows how old. She may not know herself.

She is wrapped in layers of dark fabric and bone-bead necklaces, each bead carved with a tiny hexagrammic ward. Her face is a landscape of wrinkles so deep they cast their own shadows. Her eyes are sharp, black as polished obsidian — and completely blind. She sees with something else entirely. Her hands are steady as stone. She smells of incense, warp-ozone, and something older than either.

Madam Eva speaks in riddles — not from mystical affectation, but because the future she perceives is genuinely non-linear and cannot be expressed in straight sentences. She is darkly amused by suffering, not from cruelty but from the exhaustion of someone who has seen every possible outcome and knows most of them end badly.

She is neither good nor evil in any simple sense. She serves the Tarot — fate's will, the Emperor's will, or some incomprehensible force that supersedes all other loyalties. She aids those who oppose Strahd, yet her relationship with him is ancient and ambiguous. She knows things she should not know: the Acolytes' names, what they had for breakfast, the secret fears they have never spoken aloud.

Her Tarot readings are genuine. The cards do not lie, though they are often cruel.

system.description: A genuine psychically-attuned Emperor's Tarot deck. The cards are warm to the touch and faintly luminescent. Used for the campaign's central randomization mechanic (5-card draw).
Dozens of bone-bead necklaces and woven talismans. Provide AP 3 against psychic attacks only. Also serve as the anchor for her 5m Unreadable aura.
A gnarled walking stick. Theoretically a weapon. Madam Eva has never used it as one.

Baba Lysaga dwells in the Drowned Ruins of Berez, in a walking hab-unit animated by warp energy. She is impossibly old — ancient beyond biology, her body sustained by centuries of warp-infusion. Her skin ripples and shifts like water. Her fingers are too long, her smile too wide, her eyes solid black from edge to edge.

She claims to be Strahd's 'spiritual mother' — she was present at his birth, whispered dark lore to him throughout his childhood, and considers herself responsible for shaping him into the creature he became. Her devotion to Strahd is absolute, maternal, and deeply insane. She will destroy anything that threatens her 'son.'

She is Psy Rating 7 — the most powerful psyker on Barovus after Strahd himself. She commands warp-fire, telekinesis, domination, flesh-warping, and can sustain a devastating warp storm. She fights from inside her walking hab-unit, using its bulk and armour as both weapon and shield.

She holds the second Sacred Seed, stolen from the Recaf Distillery.

WALKING HAB-UNIT:
  Type: Walker / Warp-Animated Construct
  Structural Integrity: 30
  Armour: 20 (all facings)
  Movement: 4/8/12/16
  Weapons: 2x Stomping Legs (2d10+10 I, Pen 5, Concussive [2]); Warp-Animated Tendrils (1d10+8 R, Snare — Strength –10 or Grappled, 1d10+8 R/round while grappled)
  Traits: Size (Enormous), Warp-Animated
  Special: Not a true machine — animated by warp energy. Cannot be affected by Tech-Use or haywire. Vulnerable to holy/blessed weapons (ignore 10 points of Armour). If reduced to 0 SI, collapses — Lysaga passes Ag test or takes 2d10 I, then fights on foot.

system.description: A gnarled staff of petrified wood, older than Barovus itself.
The second Sacred Seed, stolen from the Recaf Distillery. Blessed by a Ministorum saint centuries ago. Lysaga keeps it as a trophy.
A collection of stolen holy relics — aquila pendants, prayer beads, Ministorum icons — all defiled and repurposed as warp-fetishes. Carrying these inflicts 1d5 CP.
